slidelink.displaytext: Custom Component Integration Into Qsys System
Nios II Custom Instruction User Guide

c language software interface 19 nios ii sbt for eclipse generates macros automatically during software build processmacros defined in system.h file e.g. user c-code that references bitswap custom instruction #define alt_ci_<your instruction_name>(instruction arguments) #include “system.h”int main (void){ int a = 0x12345678; int a_swap = 0; a_swap = alt_ci_bswap(a); return 0; }

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello and welcome to Altera’s online training Using the Nios II Processor - Custom Components and Instructions. My name is Doug and I’ll be the instructor for this session.

You can create custom components to perform proprietary functions and integrate them into Nios II processor systems. For performance-critical systems that spend most CPU cycles executing a specific section of code, it is a common technique to create a custom component that implements the same function in hardware. This approach offers a double performance benefit: the hardware implementation is faster than software; and the processor is free to perform other functions in parallel while the custom component operates on data.

With the component editor in Qsys you can create custom components that will seamlessly connect to the fabric.

We are going to talk about briefly how to connect custom components to your Nios II System and Qsys Interconnect.
The custom components could be custom user logic that is placed inside your Qsys system module. The peripheral could also exist outside of your Qsys system module but still located on the same FPGA, or you can go off chip to connect to the custom components by routing signals to the pins of the FPGA and connecting to some other board component. So there are three variants of custom components.

The premise of Altera’s tool flow is to make it as easy as possible for you to connect your custom component to the system interconnect so you can focus your time and effort designing the functionality of the component. You can use the Qsys component editor to make it very easy to stitch the ports from your component to the equivalent System Interconnect signal types.

Here we see how you can map the ports from your component in this case a Verilog module called my_peripheral to the equivalent Qsys Avalon MM Standard Interface signal types.

My Peripheral is a MM Slave component so I’ll map the clk to the clk signal, wr_data to writedata and so forth. For signals that do not fit in the paradigm of the standard interface, such as the the signal_out output signal here, we can map them to the export signal of the conduit interface.

The tool that allows you to map the signals in your component onto their appropriate Avalon interface and signal types is called the “Component Editor”. You launch it from within Qsys either directly from the IP Catalog or through the File menu.

The Component Editor has a number of tabs.

The first tab is the Component Type tab. Basic information about the component, such as its name, a description of the component, as well as a component icon and links to documentation for the component, can be entered here. Some of this information will appear in the component’s parameter editor as you’ll see in a moment. The Display Name is how the component will appear in the Component Library. The Group is the folder in the Component Library where the component will appear. Components can be put in existing folders by selecting one from the list or in a custom folder by entering a new folder name. This new component will be available in a new folder called Custom Logic.

The second tab in the component editor is the HDL Files tab. Here you can add the HDL files that makes up your peripheral, and specify the top level of the component hierarchy if necessary. <click> It also lets you choose whether each file is used for simulation and/or synthesis. When HDL files are added, analysis and elaboration is run on the file so errors will be caught, so that the component editor can understand the structure of the code, the input output signals, and the parameters associated with the component.

The next tab is the Signals Tab, here you can map the signals in your component to the Avalon Standard Interface signal names. You can also create interfaces here if you need to.

If you’ve named signals in your component HDL file cleverly as we did here, then the component editor will automatically recognize and map the signals, and you can avoid having to manually map signals

If the HDL code for your component is parameterized, those parameters or generics will shown up here, allowing you to override their default settings on an instance-by-instance basis in your system.


<click>
you can also preview the GUI that's shown when your IP is instantiated along with the parameters that can be overridden.

The interfaces tab lets you define all the parameters for your component’s interfaces this includes timing parameters, lets you create any new interfaces you might need, gives you the means to assign clocks and resets to interfaces, and also remove any interfaces that are not being used by the signals on the signals tab.

<click through all the animations, which scrolls you through the entire peripheral UI>

The Component Editor creates an output file called the hardware Tcl file, which captures all the settings you created in the Component Editor GUI.

The nice thing about this file is that to import your component into another Qsys project, all you have to do is make sure that Qsys can find it and the HDL and/or SDC files associated with your component.
Here is an example system where a custom component is added to the system. You can see this component has both master and slave ports that connect to the interconnect.

If you need to make changes to the Component Editor settings for your peripheral, you can re-open the component editor and make changes by right-clicking on the component in the library and select Edit. This will re-launch the Component Editor and allow you to re-generate the hardware Tcl file. This feature allows for “in-place” editing of components, so you do not have to remove and re-instantiate them for the changes to take effect. You just need to remember to refresh the system after making the changes so that Qsys re-reads all the _hw.tcl files in your project.
For more information on custom components please see the Quartus II Handbook, chapters 6 and 8.

When using the Nios II embedded processor, you can accelerate time-critical software algorithms by adding custom instructions to the Nios II processor instruction set. Using custom instructions, you can reduce a complex sequence of standard instructions to a single instruction implemented in hardware. You can use this feature for a variety of applications, such optimizing software inner loops for digital signal processing (DSP), packet header processing, and computation-intensive applications.

Nios II processor custom instructions are custom logic blocks adjacent to the ALU in the CPU’s data path. This gives system designers the ability to tailor the Nios II processor core to meet the needs of their application.

There are many levels of customization possible with custom instructions. If you have a purely combinatorial block, then the requirements for that block is you have two 32-bit data inputs and one 32bit result output. Those signals directly map to the ALU as shown here.

If you have a multi-cycle instruction then you’ll need additional signals such as clk, clk_en, reset, start, and done.

You can include up to 256 different custom instructions per processor. The 8-bit n signal allows multiple variations of your custom instruction.

You can also include additional signals which is what we call register file interface that’s only accessible through assembly language, but you can write to a register file inside your instruction, and send data to and from the CPU registers.

There is also an optional conduit exporting type interface you can add for your custom instruction to interact with outside logic or pin.

You use the component editor to import a custom instruction the same way you create a custom component. Inside the component editor, choose “nios_custom_instruction” as the interface type for your signals… custom instructions can be created using Verilog, VHDL,or EDIF format.

Once created, custom instructions will show up in the component pick list under Custom Instruction Modules folder, ready for you to add to your system and connect to the Nios II Processor.

After you instantiate the custom instruction from the IP Catalog, you can rename the custom instruction instance as would any other component. Once a custom instruction is present in the Qsys system you will be able to connect it to the Custom Instruction Master Interface of the Nios II Processor.

One of the nice things about custom instructions is that the SW interface is very straight forward. You’ll find the macro to call out your custom instruction automatically defined in the system.h file of your BSP project. The MACRO is prefaced with ALT_CI

Looking at the example here, bitswap is a simple thing to accomplish in HW but difficult in SW, so we’ll use the bit swap custom instruction to get about a 70x increase in performance. In the code here we’re using the Macro to pass the integer a to the custom instruction and the return result is stored in a_swap.
For more information about custom instructions, take a look at the Nios II Custom Instruction User Guide available at Altera.com

Deciding whether to use custom components or custom instructions really depends on your application. Both can provide significant improvements over running operations in SW only.

Compared with a Custom components, Custom Instructions can be executed in a single cycle with no setup overhead and do not need to go through the System Interconnect. For operations that have up to two inputs and one, output a Custom Instructions is the proper choice. For example with Floating Point Multiply you can easily get 30X performance improvement over optimized SW.

For more complicated algorithms such as a CRC algorithm, you can get better performance with a Custom Component, where you can possibly include DMA capabilities into your component to accelerate performance.

As a review, in this presentation, we talked about the two different ways you can add custom logic into your nios II system via either custom components which the Nios II can access through the System Interconnect or Custom Instructions which are an extension of the Nios II ALU.

Altera offers many other options for training. Our instructor-led training classes are full-day classes taught by experienced training engineers, either in a public class, on-site, or through a virtual classroom. We also feature over 200 free online training classes, just like this one, that allow you to study a topic at your own pace. To find a class, search the course catalog at the Altera training website for any topic discussed in this training. While there, you can register for a free online training or an instructor-led class.

For further information about using the Quartus II software, be sure to check out the online help as well as the Quartus II Handbook. There you’ll find detailed information and multiple examples to help you use all of the features of the Quartus II software effectively. Be sure to check out the Altera web site to find solutions to the most common technical questions and problems, view design examples, and download product literature. You can always visit MySupport to get help from Altera applications engineers or call the hotline to get live assistance. For local assistance, contact your local Altera sales office to speak with a field applications engineer. Check out the Altera wiki for up-to-date articles written by Altera engineers. Finally, the online Altera forums are a great place to connect with other Altera users to share experiences and find solutions to common issues.

One more thing: when you registered for this on-line training, you should have received a link to a short survey where you can provide feedback. We'd greatly appreciate it if you'd fill out that survey now. We're constantly updating and improving our training materials, and your feedback helps us create the materials that you want! Thank you for your feedback. My name is Doug and I want to thank you for taking this online training.
